content.question: Sam’s Lower Prices Same Prices Amy’s Lower Prices <math alttext="$300 and $400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>300</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>;</mo><mi>$</mi><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="$600 and $200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>600</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>;</mo><mi>$</mi><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Same Prices <math alttext="$100 and $700" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>;</mo><mi>$</mi><mn>700</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="$400 and $500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>400</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>;</mo><mi>$</mi><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> The above payoff matrix illustrates the daily profit for two restaurants, Amy’s and Sam’s. Each restaurant has the choice to lower prices for early bird customers or keep prices the same. The first entry in each cell indicates the profits for Amy’s, and the second entry in each cell indicates the profits for Sam’s. Each restaurant independently and simultaneously chooses its action and has complete information of the payoff matrix. Based on the information and assuming Amy’s and Sam’s do not cooperate, which action will each pursue?

choices.label: Both Amy’s and Sam’s will lower prices.
Amy’s will lower prices, and Sam’s will charge the same prices.
Amy’s will charge the same prices, and Sam’s will lower prices.
Both Amy’s and Sam’s will charge the same prices.
There is insufficient information to answer the question.

content.answer: Both Amy’s and Sam’s will lower prices.
